page.title: 13Army influence on B.S.E.
page.content: For many years Bury St. Edmunds was the headquarters of the Suffolk (later Royal Anglian) Regiment. Its part in victory at the battle of Minden against the French in 1769 is commemorated in the name of the "Minden Rose" public house, a reminder that when advancing to battle the men picked roses to wear in their hats. Their exploits are also recalled in the names of roads:- Minden Drive, Detingen Way and Gibraltar Close. Much of the former Blenheim Army Camp is now the Blenheim Industrial Estate, consisting mainly of warehouses. Part of the area is used by the Territorial Army and the cadet force.
